text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. ANT THOMPSON

Present Address: ESTON, SASK.

Pioneer Address: MIKESSTONE, SASK.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Mrs. ANT THOMPSON

Present Address: ESTON, SASK.

Pioneer Address: MIKESSTONE, SASK.

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realise that not one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

(Signed) A. L. H. 1953)
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (write at least once a week)

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Usually Monday morning

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Afternoon or evening

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates. You later wrote them mostly in the winter

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No schedule
No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? (Name of place at least once)

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? (Usually Sunday morning)

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? (Was there a "pot luck" meal?)

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? (Coffee or tea with light lunch)

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes?

Here these more frequent in later years? Give dates. (Was it a "party" mostly, or will me know)

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? (No schedule)
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, phonics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire.)

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

10. Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings?)

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? What dances were popular? Was there ever any disarrangement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Questionnaire, tree, plans, etc.)
If you have not described these in the school Questionnaire, give dates.

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe. Was a lot of after school dancing and playing a highlight?

10. What material was used by the school board for the school building? How large was it? When was it built?

11. Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?
12. What attempts at formality or "snobbery" do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, saluting, visiting, traveling ceremonially in parlor, etc.? No attempt at formality.

13. Was the obituary known in your community? Describe what you remember about obituaries, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc., that you remember!

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember! Telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you mention them.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services. It's hard to say from a perspective studied, marvelous problems met by a cooperative association & how much things are said Red cat, but on black little dogface and had mixed programs including debate on topics of the day.
3.

12. What attempts at "furnishing" or "adornment," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visiting in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the shivaree known in your community? 

Describe what you remember about shivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember; telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

At downtown the homes may have been decorated with all manner of things, as flowers, etc., and there was a lot of music and merrymaking as well.

In 1910 we visited for Billington's Band & Butterfield's Band.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember being organized established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

We organized our community in 1912.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community?

Tell when it was organized and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

Then was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

It was a very active club and had musical programs, etc.

Red cat, etc.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There are spaces at the bottom of this page for organization connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

19. Were there various organizations held by members?

20. Were you accustomed to having general talks, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers, etc.), where they were held, how often, etc., and what topics were discussed.

21. What games did boys play in summer? (Skipping rope, ball, etc.) What games did girls play in summer? (Skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Who provided the lantern and the slides? What were the slides about?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name, date when it was first organized, its activities, and purposes, who belonged (sex, race, young people), whether it included people only in certain relatively small area (for example within a school district) or was centered in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church, so they need not be included here).

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general talks, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local men, women, etc.), where they were held, how often, etc., what you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Who provided the lantern and the slides? What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (jumping rope, ball, etc.)? What games did girls play in summer (jumping rope, play house, etc.)?
The chief service of this club in the first few years was to get a Ladies' aid to the United Church (services held at school) although the Home Workers were supposed to be non-sectarian, and almost half the members were of other creeds.
The chief service of this club in the first few years was to get a Ladies' aid to the United Church (America held at school) although the Home Hobbers were supposed to be non-sectarian, and almost half the members were of other creeds.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

Dances, plays, fairs, raffles

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? In school, at home, in members' homes.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Before 1914 there were not enough boys or girls to play games.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, the principal activity or purpose, and the relatively small area (for example, within a school district) or large area centered in the town or village and included the surrounding countryside. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.)

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? (In school, at an

20. Were you accustomed to buying general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, who gave them (local ministers or teachers), special fees?

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers), special fees, tutors, etc., where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (carnival types, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? Tobogganing

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? Blind man's buff. Why is it like me.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain. The whole family took part especially on Christmas, New Year's Day and any large gathering.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. Lots of time in winter. There was not much else to do, so there was a lot of winter visiting.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. July 1907. It was held at a farm home about 25 miles south west of Milestone, Sask.

26. Who organized it? Liberals of that district.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? It was attended by people from as far as 30 or 40 miles away.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? There were foot races and a band. Most times were mostly taken up by political speeches. W.B. M. Thompson and Mr. Marton Scholtes became premier and provincial minister.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? Every family brought lunch and ate in groups.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Cold meat or sandwiches, potatoes, salad, pie, cake, coffee.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? It started at 12 noon and lasted till 5 P.M.
21. Did the whole family join in such games? Explain. Why so at this time?

22. Blind man's buff. Why so at this time?

23. All work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrows, beads, etc.? How did they make them?

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Tell where.

26. Who organized it? Tell who attended.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group? If for a smaller group, explain why.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?

29. If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

30. What arrangements were made for eating? Was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding. As this was people I all political views present. There was quite a lot of heckling, but W.A. Smith well was master of the situation and handled the crowd very well.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

That was the largest picnic I remember in the early days; others were mostly family or small community affairs. At the annual affairs we provided our own amusement such as races for children and grown-ups. We would choose sides for a ball game both men and women playing.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

At the early community picnics everyone who cared to come were welcome. We just let it be known there would be a picnic at a given place. How one wanted we invited.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Tug-of-war for men, races for men women children. Baseball where sides were chosen by leaders.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Baseball

What year? About 1920. How long did it continue? About 2 years.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this photo which you remember as outstanding by this

mentality all political news present plus more

a lot of heckling and wasn't there will be making of

the situation and handled the crowd very well

34. Describe any different kinds of pictures which you knew of in the early days,

plastic, etc., that were held and differences in numbers attending activities.

That was the largest the house. Remembered in the

early days often. We really thought family in parallel

community affairs. At the end of the children and

an own ambition group as names for ball game both

green and brown playing

35. What changes have you noticed in pictures since the first years? If possible,

give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years,

yelling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly

young people). Ball was for men. Have you seen women

children. Ball will be miles ahead by

leaders

37. For what race was the first team organized in your community to play against

neighboring teams?

What year? about 1920 How long did it continue? About 8 years

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, playing dates of

organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played

against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered

in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it

was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
42. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? [Handwritten text not legible]

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plans?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? [Handwritten text not legible]

When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 1st or July 4th). [Handwritten text not legible]

43. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

44. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

I was so lonely I came west and had no intention of staying so brought my books.

45. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? [Handwritten text not legible]

What kind of books and how many? [Handwritten text not legible]

46. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? [Handwritten text not legible]

47. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

48. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

49. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

50. Was there a school library? When was it begun?

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

51. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
12. What books did you bring with you? (List at least five.) How many did you bring? (List at least five.)

13. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

14. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? (Give details.)

15. Did you buy any books other than those listed above?

16. What books were sent to you by others in your family?

17. Have you ever had any traveling library books in your community or school? (Give details.)

18. Was there a school library? If so, when was it begun?

19. Did parents ever use their children's school texts as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town?
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence?
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

   Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it
   contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian,
   and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to
    the west? [Handwritten: Family Harold, Grain Growers Guide.]

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped cer-
    tain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading
    material? [Handwritten: Yes]
    Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your
    early days in the west a hardship? Explain. [Handwritten: Yes]
50. Have there ever been a community library in your district or town? If so, when did it start?
   In what was it situated?
   Is it still in existence?

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to then? (List name and date.)
   Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading matter?

52. Describe later changes in your subscription habits, telling why you subscribed or not.

53. What books or papers that you brought to the meet with you do you still have?

54. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? (An accordion)

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment? In early years in the West? Describe daily life in your home.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? (The old songs and old stories.)

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? When was it started? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? (Include dates, if possible.)

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home life?

In the community, there was a musical society called the

61. Was "folk music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How many were in it? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

66. Do you have any collections, such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, etc.? If so, describe them briefly.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, musical, pioneer days, not already mentioned.
